Can train-time calibration apply to federated learning?
We first compare train-time calibration in traditional centralized training versus non-IID federated learning. We train a model on the entire CIFAR-100 training dataset for 100 epochs with various train-time calibration methods, and present the results in Table 6 of Appendix B.1.
Results show that most baselines effectively calibrate in centralized settings, maintaining accuracy and exhibiting lower calibration errors. Yet, when these train-time calibration techniques are applied to FL, as depicted in Table 1, these methods often underperform in calibration and accuracy.
Notably, methods like DCA and MDCA that includes an auxiliary loss for calibration show robustness in federated settings.
They maintain the primary classification objective while penalizing miscalibration, preserving confidence without affecting classification, distinguishing them in FL environments.

Calibration strategy validation.
Our calibration strategy applies a higher auxiliary penalty loss to local models that significantly deviate from the received global model, addressing global calibration needs during local training.
To validate the soundness of our design, we experiment with an opposite logic, where a higher penalty is applied to local clients more similar to the received global model.
We specifically adjust the weight βmsubscript𝛽𝑚\beta_{m} for each client m𝑚m to sim​(δ(t−1),δm(t,e))−1simsuperscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑚𝑡𝑒1\texttt{sim}(\delta^{(t-1)},\delta_{m}^{(t,e)})^{-1}.
We conducted this destructive experiment to assess whether this approach affects FL and to validate our original calibration logic.
In Table 3, we applied a reverse penalty strategy to optimal configurations of our method (i.e., NUCFL (DCA+L-CKA) and (NDCA+L-CKA)) on the CIFAR-100 dataset.
The results show that using reversed logic negatively impacts the system, leading to a calibration penalty biased towards local heterogeneity and ignoring global calibration needs, thus degrading the FL system’s performance.
This even resulted in poorer performance compared to uncalibrated FL as shown in Table 1.
This experiment confirms the soundness of our design logic, which strategically prioritizes global calibration needs during local training and suggests the benefits of adhering to our approach to avoid disadvantageous effects.

This section presents additional experimental results and comparisons with FedCal Peng et al. [2024] from Section 5.2.
Table 15 provides complete comparisons across different datasets.
The results in Table 15 indicate that our proposed NUCFL outperforms FedCal.
FedCal improves local client calibration using a local scaler design and aggregates these scalers to create a global scaler for the global model.
However, relying solely on an aggregated scaler from local clients can lower global ECE but may neglect crucial interactions between global and local calibration needs.
Our method accounts for these interactions, mitigating biases toward local heterogeneity and more effectively meeting global calibration requirements.

Comparison with the existing model calibration baseline for FL.
We now conduct comparisons with the only existing model calibration framework for FL, FedCal Peng et al. [2024]. Table 4 displays the calibration results of our method alongside the baseline using FedAvg under non-IID conditions (α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5) on CIFAR-100 datatset. For the scaler used in their work, we adhered to their design, employing an MLP with layer sizes of 100-64-64-100. We see that our proposed NUCFL has shown superior performance compared to FedCal. While the use of a scaler aggregated solely from local clients can help reduce global ECE, it often overlooks the essential interaction between global and local calibration needs. Our method addresses this by considering these interactions, thus avoiding biases toward local heterogeneity and better accommodating the broader global calibration requirements, a challenge that the aggregation methods might not fully resolve.
More comparisons using other datasets are available in Appendix B.4.

Compatibility with post-hoc calibration.
Temperature scaling (TS) Guo et al. [2017] is one of the most effective post-hoc calibration methods, which adjusts a model’s logits by a scaling factor to calibrate confidence scores without affecting accuracy.
Like all post-hoc methods, TS requires a hold-off dataset to tune the model and learn the calibration parameter (i.e., temperature).
However, this need conflicts with the data privacy policies of FL, making TS impractical in such settings.
For this analysis, we set aside these privacy concerns to compare with TS, assuming that data from each client is available at the server.
Under these assumptions, we conduct non-IID (α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5) FedAvg and sample five images from each client to create a server dataset for post-hoc calibration.
Table 5 compares train-time and post-hoc calibration methods using the CIFAR-100 dataset.
Results show TS outperforming some train-time methods, like MDCA, while our method still provides superiority in both accuracy and calibration error.
Recall from Remark 2 that our NUCFL can also be complemented by post-hoc methods when a holdout dataset is available for refining the global model.
We apply post-hoc calibration on the global model using TS after train-time calibration during local training.
This combined approach shows improved performance over train-time calibration alone.
Notably, integrating TS with NUCFL yields the best results, significantly reducing error.

references:
This section presents additional experimental results and comparisons with FedCal Peng et al. [2024] from Section 5.2.
Table 15 provides complete comparisons across different datasets.
The results in Table 15 indicate that our proposed NUCFL outperforms FedCal.
FedCal improves local client calibration using a local scaler design and aggregates these scalers to create a global scaler for the global model.
However, relying solely on an aggregated scaler from local clients can lower global ECE but may neglect crucial interactions between global and local calibration needs.
Our method accounts for these interactions, mitigating biases toward local heterogeneity and more effectively meeting global calibration requirements.
